title: Custom Operators — PyTorch 2.9 documentation
text:
## Custom Operators#

Created On: Jul 28, 2025 | Last Updated On: Jul 28, 2025
Summary:
Use custom operators to havetorch.compiletreat a function as opaque.torch.compilewill never trace into the function and Inductor (the backend) will run the function as-is.
torch.compile
torch.compile
You may wish to use a custom operator in any of the following situations:
Your code calls some C/C++/CUDA code. Dynamo is a Python bytecode interpreter and generally does not know how to handle calls to C/C++/CUDA functions that are bound to Python.
Dynamo and non-strict tracing have trouble tracing through a function and you want it to be ignored bytorch.compile.
torch.compile
Please seethe Python custom ops tutorialfor more details on how to wrap a Python function into atorch.compile-understood custom operator.
torch.compile
For more advanced use cases, you may wish to use our C++ Custom Operator API; please seeherefor more information.
